question: Question_03_(b)
statement:
Let \emph{P} be a real symmetric \emph{n x n} matrix such that
\emph{P\textsuperscript{2} = P}. Also let \emph{R = I\textsubscript{n} -
2P} be the matrix that reflects a vector across a plane.

\textbf{(b)} If \emph{P} is the matrix of the projection of
$\mathbb{R}^n$ onto a subspace \emph{V} and if \emph{Q} is the matrix of
the projection of $\mathbb{R}^n$ onto the orthogonal complement
$V^\perp$, explain (either algebraically or geometrically) why \emph{PQ
= 0} and \emph{RQ = Q}.
sols:
Why is $PQ = 0$

$Px$ is in the subspace$V$ and $Qx$ will be in the subspace orthogonal
to $V$. So it is easy to imagine that if $y$ is in $V$ then $Qy$ will be
the zero vector meaning $Qy = 0$. To get a vector in $V$ from any vector
in$R^n$ we simply use $y = Px$. Substituting this into the first
equation we get $Q(Px) = QPx = 0$ and because x does not have to be a
zero vector $QP=0$. The same logic is true for the opposite case so
$PQ=0$.

To see RQ = Q we can solve algebraically

$RQ = (I - 2P)Q = Q - 2PQ$

but as seen above $PQ = 0$

so $Q - 2PQ = Q$
